newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil roasters finally receive imported coffee.
newsitem.headline: Brazil roasters finally receive imported coffee.

text.p: Brazilian roasters have won a battle to release 9,700 60-kg bags of imported Ecuadorean coffee which arrived in Brazil in mid-April, said the superintendent of the Brazilian Coffee Industry (Abic) which represent roasters.
"Since last week, the coffee has been released," said Abic's Paulo Motta.
The coffee had been refused release by the Agriculture Ministry which claimed that the amount of pesticides was above levels fit for human consumption.
However, a Brazilian agricultural institute subsequently proved that was not true.
"The coffee is of good origin and is in good condition and fit for human consumption," said Julio Garcia, Abic's lawyer.
The roasters imported the coffee at $92 a bag at a time when high domestic prices were $125 per bag, Motta said.
"By importing this coffee, we wanted to show that the domestic coffee policy was incorrect," Motta said.
The government treasury will pay for losses incurred during the time the coffee was retained at the port, Garcia said.
